titlestmt.title: The Good Farmer Copy 1 : electronic edition

1 XML file approx. 12KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC

filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesNovember 2024
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of forty-seven monochrome wash drawings created by Blake between c. 1774 and c. 1786.
The use of monochrome washes to tint a pencil or pen and ink drawing offered eighteenth-century artists several advantages. They could register gradations in tone, from the white of the untouched paper to jet black, without the more time-consuming use of actual colors. No further work was required if the wash drawing was intended as a preliminary for an uncolored engraving. A monochrome wash could also be used to underlie subsequent applications of water colors, thereby darkening selected areas to create the illusion of depth or cast motifs in shadow.
As the works presented here show, Blake made full use of monochrome washes from his earliest years as an artist. When assigned by his engraving master, James Basire, to record tombs in Westminster Abbey c. 1774-75, Blake applied black and gray washes to tint many of his drawings (Objects 1-5). These carefully executed works could then be used as preliminaries for subsequent engravings by Basire’s workshop.
Blake’s monochrome washes during his first decade as an independent artist and engraver include several interrelated groups. The seven drawings of figures from Michelangelo’s Sistine ceiling (Objects 37-43) demonstrate how copying engravings of works by Renaissance masters helped Blake learn postures and gestures he would later use in his own compositions. Other drawings provide visual evidence of how Blake developed a design from early sketches to highly finished water colors or engravings. The recto/verso drawings, Two Sketches for “Joseph Making Himself Known to His Brethren” (Objects 34 and 35), are preliminaries for the finished water color in the Fitzwilliam Museum, one of three illustrations of the biblical story of Joseph that are among Blake’s finest pictorial works of the 1780s. The three Joseph water colors are in the Archive along with a water color preliminary for Joseph Ordering Simeon to be Bound. The evolution of one of Blake’s earliest original book illustrations, a frontispiece for Thomas Commins’ Elegy Set to Music of 1786, can be traced through three variant wash drawings (Objects 45-47) and a pencil sketch also in the Archive. The four wash versions of The Good Farmer reproduced here (Objects 16-19), in addition to two pen and ink drawings of the subject previously added to the Archive, show the complex ways Blake played variations on a theme as he worked toward a final version. No such finished work is known, and thus these drawings are our only record of Blake’s engagement with this subject. Similarly, for War Unchained by an Angel, Fire, Pestilence, and Famine Following, an untraced work Blake exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1784, we have only a preliminary study (Object 6).
Blake’s illustrations to his poem Tiriel of c. 1789 are among his most accomplished monochrome wash drawings. These have been published in the Archive as an independent group coordinated with the Tiriel manuscript.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.compdate: c. 1780-85The dating is based on stylistic considerations.

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and monochrome washes

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Early history unknown; acquired at an unknown time by John Deffett Francis; given by Francis to the British Museum in Dec. 1874.

objnote.p: Blake developed this subject and basic composition through a series of seven or eight further drawings, including Butlin 120 recto, 120A recto and verso, 122 recto and verso, 123 recto, 124, and possibly untraced 125, *Christ as the Good Shepherd*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Part of a sequence of seven interrelated drawings, this design depicts a field of grain and, near it, a Christ-like figure surrounded by other figures who seek his aid. This particular drawing has been tentatively identified as an illustration of Ruth 2: 1-17 because of the addition of a gleaning woman in the foreground. The Ruth figure stands before a large area of waist-high grain (perhaps wheat). She faces left, bending over at the waist and striding forward with her right leg. Her left leg bends and extends backward; her left arm bends slightly and extends downward as she points toward the ground in front of her. Ruth's head also tilts downward as she gazes at the ground. Her long hair is gathered into a bun. She is nude from the waist up, her left breast appearing prominently below her extended arm, and she wears a long skirt. In front of Ruth, at the left edge of the grain field, stands the "good farmer," who, if the design illustrates part of the book of Ruth, may represent Boaz. The farmer has also been identified with Christ. The farmer has short hair; he wears a long-sleeved shirt and a skirt that reaches his ankles. The farmer's body faces forward and to the right; his right leg extends forward as if walking toward Ruth, and he extends both arms toward her with his palms up. The farmer turns his head to the left to look back at the group of figures behind him. These three figures face forward and to the right. They are, from left to right: a shorter figure, perhaps a woman or child, who wears a knee-length skirt and walks toward the farmer with left leg forward and arms extended out in front; a gowned, long-haired man who kneels with arms held at his sides, palms up, and fingers spread; and an older, bearded man who kneels and raises his left arm into the air, almost touching the farmer's shoulder with his hand. To the right of the farmer, behind the edge of the grain field, stands another male figure who faces forward and crosses his right arm over his chest. He faces the viewer, and his right hand may rest on his left shoulder. In the upper left corner of the design, a set of small buildings appears in the background. Against the left border is a simple structure with a slanted roof and no visible doors or windows. In front of the house, a four-legged animal (possibly a horse?) appears to be eating from a raised trough or bucket. Below and to the right of this animal may be a pile of feed, another animal, or some other object; even further to the right, a human figure or animal appears to crawl along the ground. It may be dead or dying. Behind the house and these figures is a longer building. The haphazard lines at the right of this building may suggest that it is on fire or in some way damaged. Further in the background, immediately behind the long building, is a smaller house with a chimney. Smoke rises from the chimney and floats to the right. In the upper righthand corner, another field of grain appears in the distance. Curved lines at the edges of the field suggest that it may be partially surrounded by other vegetation. Alternatively, these lines may suggest fire, as harsher diagonal lines appear atop the grain, and darkened clouds (perhaps smoke) appear above it. To the right of the field stand six(?) figures. They are, from left to right: a figure who faces left and raises his(?) arms horizontally toward the field, holding some sort of tool; another figure standing beside him, also facing the field; a figure that faces the viewer but turns her(?) head to the right and holds something in her arms (perhaps an infant); the babe in arms; a curved line suggesting the head of another figure; and a figure who faces forward and to the right, as if looking toward something beyond the design's right border. Mountains fill the center of the design's background, just above the farmer's head. Dark clouds rise above the mountains, perhaps mingling with smoke from the chimney at left and the fire at right.

component.illusobjdesc: The Ruth figure stands before a large area of waist-high grain (perhaps wheat). She may be gathering this grain. Ruth faces left, bending over at the waist and striding forward with her right leg. Her left leg bends and extends backward; her left arm bends slightly and extends downward as she points toward the ground in front of her. Ruth's head also tilts downward as she gazes at the ground. Her long hair is gathered into a bun. She is nude from the waist up, her left breast appearing prominently below her extended arm, and she wears a long skirt.

In front of Ruth, at the left edge of the grain field, stands the "good farmer," who, if the design illustrates part of the book of Ruth, may represent Boaz. He has also been identified as Christ. The farmer has short hair; he wears a long-sleeved shirt and a skirt that reaches his ankles. The farmer's body faces forward and to the right; his right leg extends forward as if walking toward Ruth, and he extends both arms toward her with his palms up. The farmer turns his head to the left to look back at the three figures behind him.

At left of the "good farmer," three figures face forward and to the right. They appear to be asking him for aid. Leftmost stands a shorter figure, perhaps a woman or child, who wears a knee-length skirt but appears to be nude from the waist up. Her hair may be pulled into a bun. The figure strides rightward with her left foot forward; her right leg extends backward, and she stands on the toes of her right foot as she leans in the farmer's direction. Her arms extend in front of her, nearly horizontally, and her hands are cupped together, palms up, as if asking for food or alms. She gazes toward the right side of the design, looking toward the field grain.

At left of the "good farmer," three figures face forward and to the right. The middle figure is a gowned, long-haired man or woman who kneels in supplication before the farmer. The figure holds his(?) bent arms slightly out and forward from his sides, with fingers spread and palms facing out. He gazes up toward the farmer.

At left of the "good farmer," three figures face forward and to the right. They appear to be asking him for aid. Rightmost kneels an older, bearded man wearing a long-sleeved gown. He kneels, leans forward, and raises his bent left arm into the air. The fingers of his left hand touch or almost touch the farmer's right shoulder. The old man's mouth may open as he gazes upward toward the farmer's face.

The Ruth and farmer figures in the foreground stand near a large area of waist-high grain (perhaps wheat). A second grain field appears in the background, near the design's upper righthand corner. This second field may be on fire, as smoke appears to rise from it. Curved lines at the edges of the field suggest that it may be partially surrounded by other vegetation.

In the upper lefthand corner of the design, a set of small buildings appears in the background. Against the left border is a simple structure, perhaps a house or barn, with a slanted roof and no visible doors or windows. Behind the house is a longer building. The haphazard lines at the right of this building may suggest that it is on fire or in some way damaged. Further in the background, immediately behind the long building, is a smaller house with a chimney. There may be a window on the side of this house, near its roof.

In front of the three buildings at upper left, a four-legged animal (possibly a horse?) faces to the right and appears to be eating from a raised trough or bucket. Below and to the right of this animal may be a pile of feed or some other object, perhaps another animal; even further to the right, a human figure or animal appears to be lying down or crawling along the ground. It could be dead or dying.
To the right of the smaller field in the design's upper righthand corner are six(?) figures.

To the right of the field at upper right are six(?) figures. Leftmost stands a figure who faces left and raises his arms horizontally toward the field, holding some sort of tool. He may be harvesting the grain with a scythe or sickle.
To the right of the field at upper right are six(?) figures. To the right of the man holding the tool stands another figure, of indeterminate gender, also facing left toward the field.

To the right of the field at upper right are six(?) figures. In the center of the group is a figure who faces the viewer but turns her(?) head to the right and holds something in her arms (perhaps an infant). She could be the child's mother.

To the right of the field at upper right are six(?) figures. The woman in the center of the group may hold an infant in her arms. Vertical lines may suggest that the child reaches upward toward its mother.
To the right of the field at upper right are six(?) figures. Above and to the right of the woman in infant appears a curved line that suggests the head of another figure.

To the right of the field at upper right are six(?) figures. Rightmost stands a figure of indeterminate gender who faces forward and to the right, as if looking toward something beyond the design's right border.
Distant mountains fill the center of the design's background, just above the farmer's head.

Smoke rises from the chimney in the cluster of buildings at left and floats to the right. Dark clouds fill the sky above the mountains, perhaps mingling with smoke from the chimney at left and the fire at right.
